div1.head: λιχανός
div1.sense: the fore-finger, from its use in licking up, Luc.

div1.head: λιχμάζω
div1.sense: = λιχμάω, Hes.
trans. to lick, Ionic 3rd sg. imperf. λιχμάζεσκε Mosch.

div1.head: λιχμάω
div1.sense: to lick with the tongue, of snakes, Eur.:—Mid., ἐλιχμῶντο περὶ τὴν κεφαλήν played like serpents round the head, Ar.

div1.head: λιχνεία
div1.sense: daintiness, greediness, Xen., Plat.

div1.head: λιχνεύω
div1.sense: to lick, Luc.
to lick up:— metaph. to desire greedily, covet, δόξαν Plut.

div1.head: λιχνοβόρος
div1.sense: nice in eating, dainty, Anth.

div1.head: λίχνος
div1.sense: dainty, lickerish, greedy, Xen., Plat.
metaph. curious, Eur.

div1.head: λίψ
div1.etym: from λείβω, because it brought wet
div1.sense: the SW. wind, Lat. Africus, Hdt., Theocr.

div1.head: λίψ2
div1.etym: only in gen. and acc. λιβάς or λίβος being used as nom.
div1.sense: a stream, Aesch.: a draught, Aesch.

div1.head: λιψουρία
div1.sense: desire of making water, natural needs, Aesch.

div1.head: λοβός
div1.sense: the lobe of the ear, Il.
the lobe of the liver, Aesch., Eur.: generally, the liver, Aesch.

div1.head: λογάδην
div1.sense: by picking out, of stones for building, Thuc.; of soldiers, Plut.

div1.head: λογάριον
div1.sense: λ. δύστηνα wretched petty speeches, Dem.

div1.head: λογάς
div1.sense: gathered, picked, chosen, of picked men, Hdt., Eur., etc.
λ. λίθοι unhewn stones, taken just as they were picked, cf. λογάδην.

div1.head: λογεῖον
div1.sense: properly a speaking-place: in the Attic theatre, the part of the stage occupied by the speakers, Lat. pulpitum, Plut., etc.

div1.head: λογία
div1.sense: a collection for the poor, NTest.

div1.head: λογίδιον
div1.sense: a little fable or story, Ar.

div1.head: λογίζομαι
div1.sense: to count, reckon, calculate, compute, Hdt.; λ. ἀπὸ χειρός to calculate off hand, Ar.:—c. acc. rei, λ. τοὺς τόκους to calculate the interest, Ar.; τρεῖς μνᾶς ἀναλώσας λογίσασθαι δώδεκα to spend 3 minae and set down 12, Ar.
c. acc. et inf. to reckon or calculate that, Hdt., Dem.
λ. τί τινι to set down to oneʼs account, charge to one, Lat. imputare, Dem., NTest.
λογ. ἀπό . . to deduct from . . , Dem.
without reference to numbers, to take into account, calculate, consider, Hdt., Attic; λ. περί τινος to form calculations about . . , Hdt., Xen.

c. acc. et inf. to count, deem, consider that . . , Hdt., Attic; with the inf. omitted, to reckon or account so and so, τὸν καθʼ ἡμέραν βίον λογίζου σόν Eur.; μίαν ἄμφω τὰς ἡμέρας λ. to count both days as one, Xen.
c. inf. fut. to count or reckon upon doing, to calculate or expect that . . , Hdt., Xen.;—c. acc. only, to count upon, Soph.
to conclude by reasoning, infer that a thing is, Plat., Xen.
the aor1 ἐλογίσθην and sometimes perf. λελόγισμαι are used in pass. sense, to be counted or calculated, Xen.

div1.head: λόγιμος
div1.sense: worth mention, notable, remarkable, famous, Hdt.

div1.head: λόγιον
div1.sense: an announcement, oracle, Hdt.; in pl. oracles, Hdt., Eur., etc.

div1.head: λόγιος
div1.sense: versed in tales or stories (λόγος IV): as Subst. a chronicler, annalist, Hdt.
generally learned, erudite, Arist., etc.
skilled in words, eloquent, Eur., Plut.

div1.head: λογισμός
div1.sense: a counting, reckoning, calculation, computation, Thuc., Plat.:—in pl. arithmetic, Xen., Plat.
an account, bill, Dem.
without reference to number, calculation, consideration, reasoning, Thuc., Dem.
an argument, conclusion, Xen.
reasoning power, reason, Xen.

div1.head: λογιστέος
div1.sense: one must calculate or subtract, Dem.

div1.head: λογιστήριον
div1.sense: the place at Athens where the λογισταί met, Oratt.

div1.head: λογιστής
div1.sense: a calculator, teacher of arithmetic, Plat.
a calculator, reasoner, Ar., Dem.
in pl. auditors, at Athens, ten members of the βουλή, to whom magistrates going out of office submitted their accounts, Dem., etc.

div1.head: λογιστικός
div1.sense: skilled or practised in calculating, Xen., Plat.:— ἡ λογιστική (sc. τέχνη) , arithmetic, Plat.
endued with reason, rational, Arist.:— τὸ λ. the reasoning faculty, Plat.
using oneʼs reason, reasonable, Xen.

div1.head: λογογραφέω
div1.sense: to write speeches, Plut.

div1.head: λογογραφία
div1.sense: a writing of speeches, and, generally, of prose, Plat.

div1.head: λογογραφικός
div1.sense: of or for writing speeches or prose, Plat.

div1.head: λογογράφος
div1.sense: a prose-writer:—the early Greek chroniclers are so called by Thuc.
like λογοποιός II, a speech-writer, one who lived by writing speeches for others to deliver, Plat., etc.

div1.head: λογολέσχης
div1.sense: a prater, Anth.

div1.head: λογομαχέω
div1.sense: to war about words, NTest.

div1.head: λογομαχία
div1.sense: a war about words, NTest.

div1.head: λογοποιέω
div1.sense: to invent stories, to write, compose, Plat.
to fabricate tales, of newsmongers, Thuc., Dem., etc.
to write speeches (v. λογοποιός II), Plat.

div1.head: λογοποιία
div1.sense: tale-telling, news-mongering, Theophr.

div1.head: λογοποιικός
div1.sense: of or like a λογοποιός: ἡ -κὴ τέχνη, λογογραφική, Plat.

div1.head: λογοποιός
div1.sense: a prose-writer, esp. an historian, chronicler, Plat., etc.
a writer of fables, Hdt., Plut.
= λογογράφος II, Plat.
a tale-teller, newsmonger, Dem.

div1.head: λόγος
div1.sense: (A) the word or that by which the inward thought is expressed, Lat. oratio; and, (B) the inward thought itself, Lat. ratio.
Lat. vox, oratio, that which is said or spoken:
a word, pl. words, i. e. language, talk, Hom., etc.; λόγου ἕνεκα, Lat. dicis causa, merely for talkingʼs sake, Plat.; λόγῳ in word, in pretence, opp. to ἔργῳ (in deed, in reality), Hdt., Attic
a word, saying, statement, Thuc.: an oracle, Pind., Plat.:— a saying, maxim, proverb, Pind., Aesch.
an assertion, promise, Soph.
a resolution, κοινῷ λ. by common consent, Hdt.
a condition, ἐπὶ λόγῳ τοιῷδε Hdt.
a command, Aesch.
speech, discourse, conversation, εἰς λόγους ἐλθεῖν, συνελθεῖν, ἀφικέσθαι τινί Hdt., Attic; λόγου μεῖζον, κρεῖσσον beyond expression, Hdt., Thuc.; λόγου ἄξιον worth mention, Hdt.
right of speech, power to speak, λόγον αἰτεῖσθαι Thuc.; διδόναι Xen.
talk about one, report, repute, Lat. fama, λόγος, Hdt., Attic; λόγος ἐστί, λόγος ἔχει, κατέχει, φέρεται, c. acc. et inf., so the story goes, Lat. fama fert, Hdt., Attic
speech, language, Plat.
a saying, tale, story, opp. on the one hand to mere fable (μῦθος) , on the other, to regular history (ἱστορία) , Hdt., Thuc., etc.: then, a fictitious story, fable, like those of Aesop, Hdt., Plat.
a narrative, and in pl. histories, history, Hdt.: in sg. one part of such a work, Hdt.
generally, prose-writing, prose, Xen., etc.
a speech, oration, Oratt.
like ῥῆμα, the thing spoken of, the subject or matter of the λόγος, Hdt., Attic
that which is stated, a proposition, position, principle, Plat.: also = ὁρισμός, a definition, Plat.
Lat. ratio, thought, reason, οὐκ ἔχει λόγον admits not of reason, Soph.; ὀρθὸς λ. Plat.; ὡς ἔχει λόγον, ὡς ἔοικεν, Dem.:— κατὰ λόγον agreeably to reason, Plat.; μετὰ λόγου Plat.
an opinion, expectation, Hdt.
a reason, ground, plea, Soph., etc.; ἐκ τίνος λόγου; on what ground? Aesch.; ἐξ οὐδενὸς λ. Soph., etc.
ὁ λόγος αἱρέει, c. acc. et inf., it stands to reason that . . , Lat. ratio evincit, Hdt.

account, consideration, esteem, regard, λόγον βροτῶν οὐκ ἔσχεν οὐδένα Aesch.; Μαρδονίου λόγος οὐδεὶς γίγνεται Hdt.; λόγου οὐδενὸς γενέσθαι to be of no account, Hdt.; λόγου ποιεῖσθαί τινα or τι, to make account of a person or thing, Hdt.;—so, ἐν οὐδενὶ λόγῳ ποιεῖσθαι Hdt.;— ἐν ἀνδρὸς λόγῳ εἶναι to be reckoned as a man, Hdt.

an account, λόγον διδόναι τινός to give an account of a thing, Hdt., Attic; so, λόγον παρέχειν Plat.; λ. λαμβάνειν παρά τινος Dem.; λ. ἀπαιτεῖν Dem.; ὑπέχειν Plat., Dem., etc.; ἐγγράφειν Dem., etc.; ἀποφέρειν Aeschin.; cf. λογιστής.
due relation, proportion, analogy, κατὰ λόγον τινός or τινί Hdt., Attic
Ὁ ΛΟΓΌΣ, the Logos or Word, comprising both senses of Thought and Word, NTest.

div1.head: λογχεύω
div1.sense: to pierce with a spear, Anth.

div1.head: λόγχη
div1.sense: a spear-head, javelin-head, Lat. spiculum, Hdt., Attic; in pl. of a single spear, the point with its barbs, τὸ ξυστὸν τῇσι λόγχῃσι ὁμοίως the shaft alike with the spear-head, Hdt.
a lance, spear, javelin, Lat. lancea, Pind., Soph., etc.
a troop of spearmen, "a plump of spears, " Soph., Eur.

div1.head: λογχήρης
div1.sense: armed with a spear, Eur.

div1.head: λόγχιμος
div1.sense: of a spear, κλόνοι λ. the clash of spears, Aesch.

div1.head: λογχόομαι
div1.sense: Pass. to be furnished with a point, Arist.

div1.head: λογχοποιός
div1.sense: making spears, Eur.

div1.head: λογχοφόρος
div1.sense: spear-bearing, Eur.: as Subst. a spear-man, pike-man, Ar., Xen., etc.

div1.head: λογχωτός
div1.sense: lance-headed, Eur., Anth.

div1.head: λοιβεῖον
div1.sense: a cup for pouring libations, Plut.

div1.head: λοιβή
div1.sense: a drink-offering, Lat. libatio, Hom.; opt. in pl., Pind., Soph.

div1.head: λοίγιος
div1.sense: pestilent, deadly, fatal, Il.

div1.head: λοιγός
div1.sense: ruin, havoc, of death by plague, Il.; by war, Il.; of the destruction of the ships, Il.

div1.head: λοιδορέω
div1.sense: to abuse, revile, Hdt., Attic; to rebuke, Xen.:—Mid. to rail at one another, Ar.
λοιδοροῦμαι is also used as Dep., c. dat., to rail at, Ar., Xen.:—c. acc. cogn., πάντα τὰ αἰσχρὰ λοιδορέονται they use all kind of foul reproaches, Hdt.

div1.head: λοιδόρημα
div1.sense: railing, abuse, an affront, Arist.

div1.head: λοιδορία
div1.sense: railing, abuse, Thuc., Plat.

div1.head: λοίδορος
div1.sense: railing, abusive, Eur.:—adv. -ρως, Strab.

div1.head: λοιμός
div1.sense: a plague, pestilence, Il., Hdt., Attic; of the plague at Athens, Thuc.
of persons, a plague, pest, Dem. (Prob. akin to λύμη, Lat. lues.)

div1.head: λοιμώδης
div1.sense: like plague, pestilential, ἡ λ. νόσος the plague, Thuc.

div1.head: λοιμώσσω
div1.sense: to have the plague, Luc.

div1.head: λοιπός
div1.sense: remaining, the rest, Lat. reliquus, Hdt., etc.; in Attic the Art. may either be in the same case as the Noun or have the Noun in gen. dependent on it, τὴν λοιπὴν ὁδὸν πορεύεσθαι Xen.; αἱ λοιπαὶ τῶν νεῶν Thuc.; also, τὸ λοιπὸν τῆς ἡμέρας Xen.
λοιπόν ἐστι, c. inf., it remains to shew, etc., Plat., Xen.; with Art., τὸ λ. ἐστι σκέψασθαι what remains is to consider, Plat.:— ὃ δὲ λοιπόν, quod superest, Aesch., etc.

often of Time, ὁ λ. χρόνος the future, Pind., Attic; πρὸς τὸν λοιπὸν τοῦ χρόνου Dem.; τὸν λ. χρόνον for the future, Soph.; τοῦ λ. χρόνου Soph.;—so in neut., τὸ λοιπόν henceforward, hereafter, Trag.; so, τὰ λοιπά Trag.
τὸ λοιπόν and τὰ λοιπά the rest, Aesch.; also λοιπόν as adv., further, besides, Plat.

div1.head: λοισθήϊος
div1.sense: λοισθήιον ἄεθλον the prize for the last in the race, Il.

div1.head: λοίσθιος
div1.sense: = λοῖσθος, Pind., Trag.:—neut. λοίσθιον, as adv. last, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: λοῖσθος
div1.sense: left behind, last, Il., Eur.;Sup. λοισθότατος last of all, Hes.

div1.head: λόκκη
div1.sense: a cloak, Anth.

div1.head: Λοκροί
div1.sense: the Locrians, of which there were three tribes, the Opuntian, opposite Euboea, Il.; the Epicnemidian, on Mount Cnemis on the Maliac Gulf, Thuc.; and the Ozolian, on the Corinthian Gulf, Thuc.:— the Epizephyrian or Zephyrian were a colony of the last on Mount Zephyrium in lower Italy, Pind., Thuc.

div1.head: Λοκρός
div1.sense: Locrian, fem. Λοκρίς, ίδος, Pind.; ἡ Λοκρίς ( sc. γῆ ) , Ar.

div1.head: Λοξίας
div1.sense: epith. of Apollo, Hdt., Trag.;—either from λοξός, the ambiguous, or from λέγω, λόγος, the speaker.

div1.head: λοξοβάτης
div1.sense: going side-ways, Batr.

div1.head: λοξός
div1.sense: slanting, crosswise, aslant, Lat. obliquus, Eur.; λοξὰ βαίνειν, of a crab, Babr.; ὁ λοξὸς κύκλος the ecliptic, Arist.

of suspicious looks, λοξὸν ὁρᾶν to look askance, Lat. limis oculis, Solon.; λοξὰ βλ. Theocr.; αὐχένα λοξὸν ἔχειν to turn the neck aside, i. e. withdraw his favour, Tyrtae.; also = Horaceʼs stare capite obstipo, Theogn.
of language, indirect, ambiguous, of oracles, Luc.

div1.head: λοξότης
div1.sense: slanting direction, obliquity, Strab.

div1.head: λοξοτρόχις
div1.sense: oblique-running, Anth.

div1.head: λόξωσις
div1.sense: obliquity, of the ecliptic, Anth., Strab.

div1.head: λοπαδαρπαγίδης
div1.sense: dish-snatcher, Anth.

div1.head: λοπάδιον
div1.sense: a platter, Ar.

div1.head: λοπάς
div1.sense: a flat dish, Ar.

div1.head: λοπός
div1.sense: the shell, husk, peel, λοπὸς κρομύοιο the peel of an onion, Od.

div1.head: λουτροδάϊκτος
div1.sense: slain in the bath, Aesch.

div1.head: λουτρόν
div1.sense: a bath, bathing place, Hom.; mostly in pl., θερμὰ λοετρά hot baths, Il.; Attic θερμὰ λουτρά Aesch., etc.; also called λουτρὰ Ἡράκλεια Ar.; ὑδάτων λουτρά water for bathing or washing, Soph.; λοῦσαι τινα λουτρόν to give one a bath, Soph.
in Poets, = σπονδαί or χοαί libations to the dead, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: λουτροφόρος
div1.sense: bringing water for bathing or washing, esp. from the fountain Callirrhoe on the wedding-day: hence, λ. χλιδή the marriage-ceremony, Eur.
as Subst., λουτροφόρος, the black urn placed on the tomb of unmarried persons, Dem., Anth.

div1.head: λουτροχοέω
div1.sense: to pour water into the bath, Anth.

div1.head: λουτροχόος
div1.sense: pouring water into the bath, the slave who did this, Od., Xen.; λ. τρίπους a three-legged kettle, in which water was warmed for bathing, Hom.

div1.head: λουτρών
div1.sense: a bathing-room, bath-house, Aesch., Xen.

div1.head: λούω
div1.sense: to wash another, properly, to wash his body (νίζω being used of the hands and feet, πλύνω of clothes), Hom.; λούσατε ἐν ποταμῶι bathe him, i. e. let him bathe, Od.:—also, λόʼ ἐκ τρίποδος washed me [with water] from a caldron, Od.

Mid. and Pass. to bathe, c. gen., λελουμένος ) Ὠκεανοῖο (of a star just risen), fresh from Oceanʼs bath, Il.;so, λούεσθαι ποταμοῖο to bathe [in water] of the river, Hom.; so, ἀπὸ κρήνης λούμενος Hdt.:—absol., λούσαντο Od., etc.; λελουμένος fresh-bathed, after bathing, Hdt.; ἦλθε λουσόμενος (Hor., ire lavatum), Ar.
in strict pass. sense, λοῦσθαι ὑπὸ τοῦ Διός, i. e. to be washed by the rain from heaven, Hdt.
in strict mid. sense, λοέσσασθαι χρόα to wash oneʼs body, Hes.

div1.head: λοφάω
div1.sense: to have a crest (λόφος), of larks, Babr.
to be ill of a crest (i. e. to have more crest than enought), Ar.

div1.head: λοφεῖον
div1.sense: a crest-case, Ar.: any case, Ar.

div1.head: λοφηφόρος
div1.sense: crested, of a lark, Babr.

div1.head: λοφιά
div1.sense: the mane on the neck and back of certain animals, the mane of horses, the bristly back of boars and hyaenas, Od., Hdt.
the back-fin of fishes, Anth.

div1.head: λοφιήτης
div1.sense: a dweller on the hills, of Pan, Anth.

div1.head: λοφνίς
div1.sense: a torch of vine bark, Anth.

div1.head: λοφόομαι
div1.sense: Pass. to be crested.

div1.head: λοφοποιός
div1.sense: a crest-maker, Ar.

div1.head: λόφος
div1.sense: properly the back of the neck of draught-cattle, because the yoke rubs it (λέπει) ; of a horse, the mane, Il.; of a man, the nape of the neck, Il.; ὑπὸ ζυγῷ λόφον ἔχειν to have the neck under the yoke, i. e. to obey patiently, Soph.
the crest of a hill, a ridge, Od., Hdt., etc.
the crest of a helmet, Lat. crista, Hom., etc.
the crest on the head of birds, Lat. crista, as of the lark, Simon.; the cockʼs comb, Ar.
of men, the tuft of hair upon the crown, λόφους κείρεσθαι to shave so as to leave tufts, Hdt.

div1.head: λόφωσις
div1.sense: a being crested, ἡ λ. ἡ τῶν ὀρνέων their crests, Ar.

div1.head: λοχαγέω
div1.sense: to lead a λόχος or company (commonly of 100 men), Xen.; c. gen., λόχου λοχηγεῖν Hdt.

div1.head: λοχαγία
div1.sense: the rank or office of λοχαγός, Xen.

div1.head: λοχαγός
div1.sense: the leader of an armed band, Soph.
esp. the captain of a company (100 men), Xen.: —but, in the Spartan army, the commander of a λόχος, Xen.; in the Persian, of 24 men, Xen.

div1.head: λοχαῖος
div1.sense: clandestine, Anth.

div1.head: λοχάω
div1.sense: to lie in wait for, to watch, waylay, entrap, Od., Hdt.
absol. to lie in wait or ambush, Il., Hdt.; in aor1 part. with another Verb, λοχήσας πολλοὺς διέφθειρεν Thuc.; Mid., λοχησάμενος Od.
c. acc. loci, to occupy with an ambuscade, ἐλόχησαν τὴν ὁδόν Hdt.

div1.head: λοχεία
div1.sense: childbirth, childbed, Eur., Plat.
= λόχευμα I, Anth.

div1.head: λοχεῖος
div1.sense: the place of childbirth, Eur.

div1.head: λοχέος
div1.sense: an ambush, Hes.

div1.head: λόχευμα
div1.sense: that which is born, a child, Eur.
in pl., childbirth, Eur.: metaph., κάλυκος ἐν λοχεύμασιν in the bursting of the bud, Aesch.

div1.head: λοχεύω
div1.sense: to bring forth, bear, Hhymn., Anth.
of the midwife, to bring to the birth. attend in childbirth, deliver, τινά Eur.:—Pass. to be delivered, bear children, Eur.; λοχευθεῖσα πυρί, of Semele, Eur.
Mid., just like Act., of the mother, Eur.; of the birthplace, Anth.
Pass., of the child, to be brought forth, born, Soph.; Προμᾱθεῖ λοχευθεῖσα brought to birth by Prometheus, Eur.: —metaph., generally, to lie embedded, ἐν τεύτλοισι Ar.

div1.head: λοχίζω
div1.sense: to lie in wait for, τινά: Pass., λοχισθέντες διεφθάρησαν they were cut to pieces by falling into an ambuscade, Thuc.
to place in ambush, Thuc.
to distribute men in companies (λόχοι) , to put them in order of battle, Hdt., Plut.

div1.head: λόχιος
div1.sense: of or belonging to childbirth, λ. νοσήματα childbed, Eur.; ὠδίνων λοχίαις ἀνάγκαις Eur.
Λοχία, epith. of Artemis Εἰλείθυια, Eur.
λόχια, ων, τά, childbirth, Anth.

div1.head: λοχισμός
div1.sense: a placing in ambush, Plut.

div1.head: λοχίτης
div1.sense: one of the same company, a fellow-soldier, comrade, Aesch., Xen.

div1.head: λοχμαῖος
div1.sense: of the coppice, Μοῦσα λ., of the nightingale, Ar.

div1.head: λόχμη
div1.sense: a thicket, coppice, copse, Od., Pind.

div1.head: λοχμώδης
div1.sense: overgrown with bushes, Thuc.

div1.head: λόχονδε
div1.sense: to ambush, for an ambuscade, Hom.

div1.head: λόχος
div1.sense: an ambush, i. e.
a place of ambush, place for lying in wait, Hom., Eur.
the act of lying in wait, λόχον εἷσαι to place an ambuscade, Hom.; λέγεσθαι ἐς λόχον to lie in ambush, Il.:—c. gen. objecti, λόχος θείοιο γέροντος the way to watch him, Od.
the men that form the ambush, Il., Eur.

any armed band, a body of troops, Od., Trag.:— a body of soldiers, a company, regiment, Xen.:—among the Spartans, a λόχος was the fourth or fifth part of a μόρα Hdt.:— ὁ ἱερὸς λ. the sacred company at Thebes, Plut.
any body of people, a union for civil purposes, Xen., etc.:—used to transl. the Rom. centuria, Plut., etc.
a lying-in, childbirth, parturition, Aesch.

div1.head: Λυαῖος
div1.sense: Deliverer, of Bacchus, Anacreont.

div1.head: λυγαῖος
div1.sense: shadowy, murky, gloomy, Eur.

div1.head: λύγδην
div1.sense: with sobs, Soph., Anth.

div1.head: λύγδινος
div1.sense: of white marble, Babr., Anth.
marble-white, Anth.

div1.head: λύγδος
div1.sense: white marble, Anth.

div1.head: λυγίζω
div1.sense: to bend or twist as one does a withe, πλευρὰν λ. of a dancer, Ar.; λ. ἀλλήλους, of wrestlers, Luc.
to throw, master, Theocr.
Pass. to bend or twist oneself like a withe, to bend aside or writhe, so as to avoid a blow, Plat., Luc.:—metaph., in perf. part. λελυγισμένος, broken, effeminate, Anth.
to turn, play, as a joint in the socket, Soph.
metaph. to be thrown or mastered, Theocr.

div1.head: λυγισμός
div1.sense: a bending, twisting, of wrestlers, Luc.: metaph., of the windings and twistings of a sophist, Ar.

div1.head: λύγκειος
div1.sense: lynx-like, Anth.

div1.head: λύγξ
div1.sense: a lynx, Eur., etc.

div1.head: λύγξ2
div1.sense: a spasmodic affection of the throat, hiccough, hiccup, λ. κενή an ineffectual retching, nothing being thrown off the stomach, Thuc.

div1.head: λύγος
div1.sense: vitex agnus castus, a willow-like tree, withy; in pl. its withes, Lat. vimina, Hom., Eur.

div1.head: λυγοτευχής
div1.sense: made of withes, Anth.

div1.head: λυγόω
div1.sense: to tie fast, Anth.

div1.head: λυγρός
div1.sense: sore, baneful, mournful, Hom., Trag.: —τὰ λυγρά bane, misery, ruin, Hom., Hes.
baneful, with an act. force, φάρμακα λυγρά Od.; γαστὴρ λυγρή the stomach that cause of bane, Od.
εἵματα λυγρά sorry garments, Od.
of persons, baneful, mischievous, Od.: sorry, i. e. weak, cowardly, Hom., Soph.
adv. -ρῶς, sorely, Il.

div1.head: Λυδιακά
div1.sense: τὰ, Λυδιακά, a history of Lydia by Xanthus.

div1.head: Λυδία
div1.sense: Lydia, in Asia Minor, Hdt.

div1.head: Λυδίζω
div1.sense: to play the Lydian, of Magnes, in reference to his play called Λυδοί, Ar.

div1.head: Λύδιος
div1.sense: of Lydia, Lydian, Pind., etc.: —Λυδία λίθος, a stone used to assay gold, Soph.; also, Λ. πέτρα Theocr.

div1.head: Λυδιστί
div1.sense: in the Lydian tongue, after the Lydian fashion, Plat.: of Music, in the Lydian mode, ἡ Λ. ἁρμονία Plat.

div1.head: Λυδός
div1.sense: a Lydian, Pind., Hdt., etc.

div1.head: λύζω
div1.sense: to have the hiccough or hiccup, to sob violently, Ar., Anth.

div1.head: λύη
div1.sense: dissolution: hence, faction, sedition, Pind.

div1.head: λύθρον
div1.sense: defilement from blood, gore, Hom., Anth.

div1.head: λυθρώδης
div1.sense: defiled with gore, Anth.

div1.head: λυκάβας
div1.etym: Prob. from *λύκη, βαίνω, the path of light, the sunʼs course.
div1.sense: a year, Od., Bion.
λυκαβαντίδες, ὧραι, ῶν, αἱ, the hours that make up the year, Anth.

div1.head: λύκαινα
div1.sense: a she-wolf, Babr., Plut.

div1.head: Λυκαῖος
div1.sense: Lycaean, Arcadian, Epith. of Zeus, Hdt., Pind., etc.
Λύκαιον, ου, his temple, Plut.; so, Λ. σήκωμα Eur.
Mount Lycaeus in Arcadia, Theocr.
Λύκαια, sc. ἱερά, τά, the festival of Lycaean Zeus, Xen.:—also = Roman Lupercalia, Plut.

div1.head: Λυκαονία
div1.sense: a district in the S. of Asia Minor, Xen., etc.: the people were Λυκάονες, οἱ, Xen.:—adv. Λυκαονιστί, in Lycaonian, NTest.

div1.head: λυκαυγής
div1.sense: of or at twilight: τὸ λυκαυγές early dawn, Luc.

div1.head: λυκέη
div1.sense: a wolf-skin, Il.

div1.head: Λύκειον
div1.sense: the Lyceum, a gymnasium with covered walks in the Eastern suburb of Athens, named after the neighbouring temple of Apollo Λύκειος, Ar., Plat., etc.

div1.head: λύκειος
div1.sense: of or belonging to a wolf, Eur.

Λύκειος, as epith. of Apollo, either as λυκοκτόνος (q. v.), or as the Lycian god (v. Λυκηγενής), or (from *λύκη) as the god of light, Aesch.; there is a play upon the doubtful meanings, Λύκειʼ ἄναξ, λύκειος γενοῦ στρατῷ δαΐῳ, Lycean lord, be a very wolf to the enemy, Aesch.

div1.head: λύκη
div1.sense: light, a Root, whence come λυκά-βας, λύχνος, etc.

div1.head: Λυκηγενής
div1.sense: of Apollo, commonly explained Lycian-born, i. e. at Patara, Il.

div1.head: Λυκιάρχης
div1.sense: president of the Lycians, Strab.

div1.head: λυκιδεύς
div1.sense: a wolfʼs whelp, Solon., Theocr.

div1.head: Λυκίηθεν
div1.sense: from Lycia, Il.

div1.head: Λυκίηνδε
div1.sense: to Lycia, Il.

div1.head: Λυκιοεργής
div1.sense: of Lycian workmanship, Hdt., Dem.

div1.head: Λύκιοι
div1.sense: the Lycians, Il., etc.
epith. of Apollo (cf. Λύκειος) , Pind., Eur.

div1.head: λυκοθαρσής
div1.sense: bold as a wolf, Anth.

div1.head: λυκοκτόνος
div1.sense: epith. of Apollo, wolf-slayer, Soph.

div1.head: λυκορραίστης
div1.sense: wolf-worrier, Anth.

div1.head: λύκος
div1.sense: Lat. lupus, a wolf, Hom.;—proverb., λύκον ἰδεῖν to see a wolf, i. e. to be struck dumb, as was vulgarly believed of any one of whom a wolf got the first look, Plat., Theocr. (so Virg., Moerim lupi videre priores); λύκος οἶν ὑμεναιοῖ, of an impossibility, Ar.

div1.head: λυκόφως
div1.sense: twilight, the gloaming, Lat. diluculum.

div1.head: λυκόω
div1.sense: to tear like a wolf:—Pass. to be torn by wolves, πρόβατα λελυκωμένα Xen.

div1.head: λυμαίνομαι
div1.sense: to treat with indignity, to outrage, to maltreat, c. acc., Hdt., Soph., etc.; c. acc. cogn., λύμης, ἥν με ἐλυμήνω Eur.:—of things, τὰς ῥήσεις ἃς ἐλυμαίνου the speeches you used to murder (as an actor), Dem.; ὀψοποιία λ. τὰ ὄψα spoils, Xen.
c. dat. to inflict indignities or outrages upon, Hdt., Ar., etc.
absol. to cause ruin, Thuc., Xen.
sometimes as Pass., λυμανθὲν δέμας Aesch.; λελυμάνθαι Dem.

div1.head: λυμαντήριος
div1.sense: injurious, destructive, Aesch.: c. gen. destroying, ruining, Aesch.

div1.head: λυμαντήρ
div1.sense: a spoiler, destroyer, Xen.

div1.head: λυμαντής
div1.sense: as adj. ruining, c. gen., Soph.

div1.head: λῦμα
div1.sense: mostly in pl. the water used in washing, washings, off-scourings, filth, Il.; λύμαθʼ ἁγνίσας ἐμά, of blood on the hands, Soph.
moral filth, defilement, in sg., Soph.
= λύμη, ruin, bane, Aesch.; of a person, λῦμα Ἀχαιῶν, i. e. Hector, Eur.

div1.head: λυμεών
div1.sense: a destroyer, spoiler, corrupter, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: λύμη
div1.sense: brutal outrage, maltreatment, maiming, Hdt., Aesch., etc.:—in pl. outrages, indignities, Hdt., Aesch.
= λῦμα, defilement, Polyb.

div1.head: λυπέω
div1.sense: to give pain to, to pain, distress, grieve, vex, annoy, Hdt., Trag., etc.; ἡ θώραξ λ. distresses by its weight, Xen.:—absol. to cause pain or grief, Soph.
of marauders, to harass, annoy by constant attacks, Hdt., Thuc., etc.

Pass. with fut. mid. to be pained, grieved, distressed, Theogn., etc.; μὴ λυπέεο be not distressed, Hdt.:—c. acc. cogn., λύπας λυπεῖσθαι Plat.:—also c. acc. rei, to grieve about a thing, Soph.:—absol. to feel pain, Eur., etc.

div1.head: λύπημα
div1.sense: pain, Soph.

div1.head: λύπη
div1.sense: pain of body, Lat. dolor, Plat.: distress, sad plight or condition, Hdt.
pain of mind, grief, Hdt., Attic.

div1.head: λυπηρός
div1.sense: of things, painful, distressing, Lat. molestus, Hdt., Attic
of persons,
in good sense, causing sorrow by oneʼs departure, Eur.
in bad sense, causing pain, troublesome, vexatious, offensive, Soph., Thuc., etc.
adv. λυπηρῶς, painfully, so as to cause pain, Soph.; λυπηρῶς ἔχει it is painful, Soph.

div1.head: λυπητέος
div1.sense: one must feel pain, Xen.

div1.head: λυπρός
div1.sense: wretched, poor, sorry, of land, Od., Hdt.
of persons, causing pain, offensive, troublesome, Aesch., Eur.
of states and conditions, painful, distressing, Aesch., Eur.
adv., λυπρῶς ἔφερεν, aegre ferebat, Eur.

div1.head: λυπρότης
div1.sense: poverty, of land, Strab.

div1.head: λυπρόχωρος
div1.sense: with poor land, Strab.

div1.head: λυραοιδός
div1.sense: one who sings to the lyre, Anth.:— contr. λυρῳδός, Anth., Plut.

div1.head: λύρα
div1.sense: Lat. lyra, a lyre, a Greek musical instrument like the κιθάρα, invented by Hermes, with seven strings, Hhymn., Eur.

div1.head: λυρίζω
div1.sense: to play the lyre, Anacreont.

div1.head: λυρικός
div1.sense: of or for the lyre, lyric, Anacreont.
as Subst., a lyrist, Anth., Plut.

div1.head: λυρογηθής
div1.sense: delighting in the lyre, Anth.

div1.head: λυρόεις
div1.sense: fitted for the lyre, lyric, Anth.

div1.head: λυροθελγής
div1.sense: charmed by the lyre, Anth.

div1.head: λυροκτυπία
div1.sense: a striking the lyre, Anth.

div1.head: λυροποιικός
div1.sense: ἡ -κή, sc. τέχνη, the art or craft of lyre-making, Plat.

div1.head: λυροποιός
div1.sense: a lyre-maker, Plat.

div1.head: Λυσάνδρια
div1.sense: a festival in honour of Lysander, Plut.

div1.head: λυσανίας
div1.sense: ending sorrow, Ar.

div1.head: λυσίγαμος
div1.sense: dissolving marriage, Anth.

div1.head: λυσίζωνος
div1.sense: loosing the zone, epith. of Eileithyia, who assisted women in travail, Theocr.

div1.head: λυσίκακος
div1.sense: ending evil, Theogn.

div1.head: λυσίμαχος
div1.sense: ending strife, Anth.: fem. λυσιμάχη, Ar.

div1.head: λυσιμελής
div1.sense: limb-relaxing, of sleep, etc., Od., Hes., etc.

div1.head: λυσιμέριμνος
div1.sense: driving care away, Anth.

div1.head: λύσιμος
div1.sense: able to loose or relieve, Aesch.
pass. that can be redeemed, redeemable, Plat.

div1.head: λύσιος
div1.sense: releasing, delivering, Plat.

div1.head: λυσιπαίγμων
div1.sense: giving a loose to play or sport, Anacreont.

div1.head: λυσίποθος
div1.sense: delivering from love, Anth.

div1.head: λυσίπονος
div1.sense: releasing from toil, Pind.

div1.head: λύσις
div1.note: λύσις (ῠ), gen. εως Ionic ιος, ἡ,
div1.sense: a loosing, setting free, releasing, ransoming, of a slain man, Il.; λ. θανάτου deliverance from death, Od.; πενίης Theogn., etc.
absol. a means of letting loose, Soph.:— deliverance from guilt by expiatory rites, Soph.; οὐδʼ ἔχει λύσιν τὰ πήματα admit not of atonement, Soph.
a loosing, parting, λ. ψυχῆς ἀπὸ σώματος Plat.:— dissolution, πολιτείας Arist.
= δόρπου λ. a place for banqueting, Pind.

div1.head: λυσιτελέω
div1.sense: to pay what is due, and then "to pay, " i. e. to profit, avail, c. dat., λυσιτελεῖ τί τινι Ar., Plat.:—impers., λυσιτελεῖ μοι it profits me, is better for me, τεθνάναι λυσιτελεῖ ἢ ζῆν ʼtis better to be dead than alive, Andoc.; λυσιτελεῖ μοι ὥσπερ ἔχω ἔχειν it is expedient for me to be as I am, Plat.
neut. part. as Subst., τὸ λυσιτελοῦν, profit, gain, advantage, Plat., Dem.; τὰ λυσιτελοῦντα Thuc.

div1.head: λυσιτελής
div1.sense: paying what is due: hence, useful, profitable, advantageous, Plat.; τὸ λυσιτελέστατον πρὸς ἀργύριον what was most profitable in point of money, Dem.
cheap, Xen.

div1.head: λυσιτελούντως
div1.sense: usefully, profitably, Xen.

div1.head: λυσιφλεβής
div1.sense: opening the veins, Anth.

div1.head: λυσίφρων
div1.sense: releasing from care, Anacreont.

div1.head: λυσιῳδός
div1.sense: one who played womenʼs characters in male attire, Plut.

div1.head: λυσσαίνω
div1.sense: to rave, τινί against one, Soph.

div1.head: λύσσα
div1.sense: rage, fury, esp. martial rage, Il.
after Hom. raging madness, raving, frenzy, Trag.
canine madness, rabies, Xen.

div1.head: λυσσάς
div1.sense: raging mad, Eur.

div1.head: λυσσάω
div1.sense: to be raging in battle, Hdt.
to rave, be mad, Soph., Plat.
of dogs, Ar.; of wolves, Theocr.

div1.head: λύσσημα
div1.sense: a fit of madness: in pl. ravings, Eur.

div1.head: λυσσητήρ
div1.sense: one that is raging or raving mad, Il., Anth.

div1.head: λυσσομανής
div1.sense: raging mad, Anth.

div1.head: λυσσόω
div1.sense: to enrage, madden, Epic part. λυσσώων, Anth.

div1.head: λυσσώδης
div1.sense: like one raging, frantic, of martial rage, Il.
of madness, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: λυτέος
div1.sense: one must solve, Plat.

div1.head: λυτήριος
div1.sense: loosing, releasing, delivering, Aesch.:—c. gen., τῶνδʼ ἐμοὶ λυτήριος my deliverer from these things, Aesch.; ἐκ θανάτου λ. Eur.
= λύτρον, recompense, Pind.

div1.head: λυτήρ
div1.sense: one who looses, a deliverer, Eur.
an arbitrator, decider, νεικέων Aesch.

div1.head: λυτικός
div1.sense: refutative, of arguments, Arist.

div1.head: λυτός
div1.sense: that may be loosed or dissolved, Plat.
of arguments, refutable, Arist.

div1.head: λύτρον
div1.sense: a price paid,
for ransom, a ransom, mostly in pl. ransom-money, Hdt.; λύτρα λαβεῖν τινος to receive as ransom for . . , Thuc.; λύτρα ἀποδιδόναι, καταθεῖναι to pay ransom, Dem.
an atonement, συμφορᾶς for calamity, Pind.; in pl., Plat.; so also, λύτρον ἀντὶ πολλῶν NTest.
generally, a recompense, Pind.

div1.head: λυτρόω
div1.sense: to release on receipt of ransom, to hold to ransom, Plat.:—Pass. to be ransomed, Dem.

div1.head: λύτρωσις
div1.sense: ransoming, Plut.

div1.head: λυτρωτέος
div1.sense: one must ransom, Arist.

div1.head: λυτρωτής
div1.sense: a ransomer, redeemer, NTest.

div1.head: λυχνεών
div1.sense: a place to keep lamps in, Luc.

div1.head: λυχνίον
div1.sense: a lamp-stand, Theocr., Luc.

div1.head: λυχνίσκος
div1.sense: a kind of fish, Luc.

div1.head: λυχνίς
div1.sense: lychnis, a plant with a scarlet flower, Anth.
a precious stone that emits light, prob. the ruby, Luc.

div1.head: λυχνίτης
div1.sense: a precious stone of a red colour, Strab.

div1.head: λυχνοκαΐα
div1.sense: a lighting of lamps, feast of Lanterns, Hdt.

div1.head: λυχνοποιός
div1.sense: making lamps or lanterns, Ar.

div1.head: λυχνόπολις
div1.sense: city of lamps, Luc.

div1.head: λυχνοπώλης
div1.sense: a dealer in lamps or lanterns, Ar.

div1.head: λύχνος
div1.sense: pl. λύχνοι and λύχνα:— a portable light, a lamp, carried in the hand or set on a lamp-stand (λυχνίον) , Od., Hdt., Attic; περὶ λύχνων ἁφάς about lamplighting time, Hdt.
in pl. the lamp-market, Ar.

div1.head: λυχνοφόρος
div1.sense: carrying a lamp, Plut.

div1.head: λύω
div1.sense: Orig. sense, to loose:

of things, to loosen, unbind, unfasten, ζωστῆρα, θώρηκα Il.; ἀσκὸν λ. to untie a skin (used as a bottle), Od.; λ. ἡνίαν to slack the rein, Soph.; λ. γράμματα to open a letter, Eur.; στόμα λ. to open the mouth, Eur.; λ. ὀφρύν to unfold the brow, Eur., etc.:—Mid., ἐλύσατο ἱμάντα undid her belt, Il.; λύσασθαι τρίχα to unbind oneʼs hair, Bion.
of living beings,
of horses, etc., to undo, unyoke, unharness, Hom.; Mid., λύεσθαι ἵππους ὑπʼ ὄχεσφι to unyoke oneʼs horses, Il.
of men, to loose, release from bonds or prison, from difficulty or danger, Hom., Att:—Mid. to get one loosed or set free, Hes.

of prisoners, to release on receipt of ransom (ἄποινα), hold to ransom, release, Hom.; λύειν τινὰ ἀποίνων on payment of ransom, Il.:—Mid. to release by payment of ransom, to get a person released, to ransom, redeem, Hom., Attic
to give up, [θρόνον λῦσον ἄμμιν Pind.
to resolve a whole into its parts, to dissolve, break up, λ. ἀγορήν to dissolve the assembly, Hom.; also to break up the market, Xen.:— Pass., λῦτο ἀγών Il.; ἐλύθη ἡ στρατιά Xen.
to loosen, slacken, σπάρτα λέλυνται, i. e. have rotted, Il.

to loosen, i. e. weaken, relax, λῦσέ οἱ γυῖα made his limbs slack or loose, i. e. killed him, Il.; λ. μένος τινί Il.; but, καμάτωι γούνατʼ ἔλυσαν made the knees weak with toil, Od.:—so in Pass., λύντο δὲ γυῖα, as the effect of death, sleep, weariness, fear, etc., Il., etc.; γυῖα λέλυντο Hom., etc.
to undo, bring to naught, break down, destroy, Hom.: and generally, to undo, do away with, put an end to, Lat. dissolvere, Hom., Attic; λ. βίον, i. e. to die, Eur.
to repeal, annul, do away with, Hdt., etc.; λ. ψῆφον to rescind a vote, Dem.:— Pass., λέλυται πάντα all ties are broken, Dem.
to solve a problem or difficulty, Plat.
to refute an argument, Arist.
to unravel the plot of a tragedy, Arist.
to break a law or treaty, Hdt., Thuc.
to solve, fulfil, accomplish, τὰ μαντεῖα Soph.
to atone for, make up for, Lat. luere, Soph., Eur.
μισθοὺς λύειν to pay wages in full, Xen.

τέλη λύειν λυσιτελεῖν, to pay, profit, avail, ἔνθα μὴ τέλη λύει φρονοῦντι where it boots not to be wise, Soph.; also λύει alone, much like λυσιτελεῖ, λύει ἄλγος Eur.; φημὶ τοιούτους γάμους λύειν βροτοῖς Eur.

div1.head: λωβάομαι
div1.sense: to treat despitefully, to outrage, maltreat, λώβην λωβᾶσθαί τινα to do one despite, Il.: esp. to maim, mutilate, Hdt.; λ. βίον to make ruin of oneʼs life, Soph.; λ. τοὺς νέους to corrupt the youth, Plat.:—sometimes, like λυμαίνομαι, c. dat., Ar., Plat.:—absol. to do despite, act outrageously, Il.
the perf. is used in pass. sense, λελωβημένος mutilated, Hdt., Plat.; also aor1 pass., μεγάλας λώβας λωβηθείς Plat.

div1.head: λωβεύω
div1.sense: to mock, make a mock of, τινά Od.

div1.head: λώβη
div1.sense: despiteful treatment, outrage, dishonour, Hom., Hdt., Attic:—esp. mutilation, maiming, Hdt.
of persons, a disgrace, Lat. opprobrium, λώβην εἶναι Il.

div1.head: λωβητήρ
div1.sense: one who treats despitefully, a foul slanderer, Il.; a destroyer, of the Furies, Soph.
pass. a worthless wretch, Il.

div1.head: λωβητής
div1.sense: λ. τέχνης one who disgraces his trade, Ar.

div1.head: λωβητός
div1.sense: despitefully treated, outraged, Il., Soph.
act. insulting, abusive, Soph.

div1.head: λωΐων
div1.sense: more desirable, more agreeable, and (generally) better, τόδε λώιόν ἐστι Hom.; and as adv. better, Od.:—we also find a comp. λωΐτερος, ον, in neut., λωίτερον καὶ ἄμεινον Od.—In Attic λῴων was used as comp. of ἀγαθός.
Sup. λῷστος, η, ον Theogn., Attic; τὰ λῷστα βουλεύειν Aesch.; ὦ λῷστε my good friend, Plat.

div1.head: λῶμα
div1.sense: the border of a robe:—Dim. λωμάτιον, τό, Anth.

div1.head: Λῷος
div1.sense: a Macedon. month, answering to the Attic Βοηδρομιών, Philipp. ap. Dem.

div1.head: λώπη
div1.sense: a covering, robe, mantle, Od., Theocr.

div1.head: λωπίζω
div1.sense: to cover, cloak, Soph.

div1.head: λωποδυτέω
div1.sense: to steal clothes, esp. from bathers or travellers, Plat., Xen.
generally, to rob, plunder, Ar.

div1.head: λωποδύτης
div1.sense: one who slips into anotherʼs clothes, a clothes-stealer, esp. one who steals the clothes of bathers, or strips travellers, Soph.
generally, a thief, robber, footpad, Ar., Dem.

div1.head: λωτίζομαι
div1.sense: Mid. to choose for oneself, cull the best, Aesch.

div1.head: λώτινος
div1.sense: made of lotus-wood, Theocr.

div1.head: λώτισμα
div1.sense: a flower: metaph. the fairest, choicest, best, Eur.

div1.head: λωτόεις
div1.sense: overgrown with lotus, πεδία λωτεῦντα (Ionic for -όεντα) lotus-plains, Il.

div1.head: λωτός
div1.sense: the lotus, name of several plants.
the Greek lotus, a plant on which horses fed, a kind of clover or trefoil, Hom.
the Cyrenean lotus, an African shrub, whose fruit was the food of certain tribes on the coast, hence called Lotophagi, Od., Hdt.
the Egyptian lotus, the lily of the Nile, Hdt.
a North-African tree; from its hard black wood flutes were made:—hence Λιβὺς λωτός is used in Poets for a flute, Eur.

div1.head: λωτοτρόφος
div1.sense: producing lotus, Eur.

div1.head: λωτοφάγοι
div1.sense: the Lotus-eaters, a peaceful people on the coast of Cyrenaica, Od., Hdt.

div1.head: λωφάω
div1.sense: to rest from toil, take rest, Il.
c. gen. to take rest or abate from, recover from, χόλου Aesch.; πόνου Soph.; λ. ἀπὸ νόσου καὶ πολέμου Thuc.
to abate, of a disease, Thuc.
trans. to lighten, relieve, ὁ λωφήσων γὰρ οὐ πέφυκέ πω Aesch.

div1.head: λωφήϊος
div1.sense: relieving, λ. ἱερά expiatory offerings, Apoll.

div1.head: λώφησις
div1.sense: abatement, cessation, Thuc.
